column1: Quite apart from the approval granted by the Board of Investment for the Pe(cid:415)(cid:415)oner to be
the foreign collaborator and investor, I have already noted that the receipt of USD 250,000
and  the  fact  that  it  was  towards  the  equity  capital  of  the  1st  Respondent  have  been
acknowledged by the Respondents – vide A14 signed by the 2nd Respondent. The fact that
such monies were u(cid:415)lised as payment for the shares in the 1st Respondent and that shares
were in fact allo(cid:425)ed to the Pe(cid:415)(cid:415)oner is conﬁrmed by A3, which too has been signed by
the  2nd  Respondent,  and  is  reﬂected  in  the  Financial  Statement  and  the  Report  of  the
Auditors [A15a] as part of the Share Applica(cid:415)on Account. The subsequent allotment of
shares in the 1st Respondent to the Pe(cid:415)(cid:415)oner negates the argument of the Respondents
that  the  2nd  Respondent  was  only  helping  the  Pe(cid:415)(cid:415)oner  to  obtain  a  resident  visa  to
operate a hotel in Kandy, and that the Pe(cid:415)(cid:415)oner was not en(cid:415)tled to any shares in the 1st
Respondent. Thus, the posi(cid:415)on taken up by the Respondents that the Pe(cid:415)(cid:415)oner was not
en(cid:415)tled to shares in the 1st Respondent is not tenable.
